# San Andreas Fault

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

A continental transform fault through California between the Pacific Plate and
the North American Plate

For other uses, see [San Andreas
(disambiguation)](/wiki/San_Andreas_\(disambiguation\) "San Andreas
\(disambiguation\)").

The **San Andreas Fault** is a continental [transform
fault](/wiki/Transform_fault "Transform fault") that extends roughly 1,200
kilometers (750 mi) through [California](/wiki/California "California").[1] It
forms the [tectonic](/wiki/Tectonics "Tectonics") boundary between the
[Pacific Plate](/wiki/Pacific_Plate "Pacific Plate") and the [North American
Plate](/wiki/North_American_Plate "North American Plate"), and its motion is
[right-lateral strike-slip](/wiki/Fault_\(geology\)#strike-slip_faults "Fault
\(geology\)") (horizontal). The fault divides into three segments, each with
different characteristics and a different degree of earthquake risk. The slip
rate along the fault ranges from 20 to 35 mm (0.79 to 1.38 in)/yr.[1]

The fault was identified in 1895 by Professor [Andrew
Lawson](/wiki/Andrew_Lawson "Andrew Lawson") of [UC
Berkeley](/wiki/University_of_California,_Berkeley "University of California,
Berkeley"), who discovered the northern zone. It is often described as having
been named after [San Andreas Lake](/wiki/San_Andreas_Lake "San Andreas
Lake"), a small body of water that was formed in a valley between the two
plates. However, according to some of his reports from 1895 and 1908, Lawson
actually named it after the surrounding San Andreas Valley.[2] Following the
[1906 San Francisco earthquake](/wiki/1906_San_Francisco_earthquake "1906 San
Francisco earthquake"), Lawson concluded that the fault extended all the way
into southern California.

In 1953, geologist [Thomas Dibblee](/wiki/Thomas_Dibblee "Thomas Dibblee")
concluded that hundreds of miles of lateral movement could occur along the
fault. A project called the [San Andreas Fault Observatory at Depth
(SAFOD)](/wiki/San_Andreas_Fault_Observatory_at_Depth "San Andreas Fault
Observatory at Depth") near [Parkfield](/wiki/Parkfield,_California
"Parkfield, California"), [Monterey County](/wiki/Monterey_County,_California
"Monterey County, California"), was drilled through the fault during 2004 -
2007 to collect material and make physical and chemical observations to better
understand fault behavior [3].

## Fault
zones[[edit](/w/index.php?title=San_Andreas_Fault&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Fault zones")]

### Northern[[edit](/w/index.php?title=San_Andreas_Fault&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Northern")]

See also: [Calaveras Fault](/wiki/Calaveras_Fault "Calaveras Fault") and
[Hayward Fault Zone](/wiki/Hayward_Fault_Zone "Hayward Fault Zone")

[![A map tracing all the fault lines in the Bay Area, and listing
probabilities of earthquakes occurring on
them.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Eq-prob.jpg/290px-
Eq-prob.jpg)](/wiki/File:Eq-prob.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Eq-prob.jpg "Enlarge")

A map displaying each of the seven major fault lines in the [San Francisco Bay
Area](/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay_Area "San Francisco Bay Area"), and the
probability of an [M6.7](/wiki/Magnitude_\(earthquake\) "Magnitude
\(earthquake\)") earthquake or higher occurring on each fault line between
2003 and 2032.

The northern segment of the fault runs from
[Hollister](/wiki/Hollister,_California "Hollister, California"), through the
[Santa Cruz Mountains](/wiki/Santa_Cruz_Mountains "Santa Cruz Mountains"),
epicenter of the [1989 Loma Prieta
earthquake](/wiki/1989_Loma_Prieta_earthquake "1989 Loma Prieta earthquake"),
then up the [San Francisco Peninsula](/wiki/San_Francisco_Peninsula "San
Francisco Peninsula"), where it was first identified by [Professor
Lawson](/wiki/Andrew_Lawson "Andrew Lawson") in 1895, then offshore at [Daly
City](/wiki/Daly_City,_California "Daly City, California") near [Mussel
Rock](/wiki/Mussel_Rock "Mussel Rock"). This is the approximate location of
the epicenter of the [1906 San Francisco
earthquake](/wiki/1906_San_Francisco_earthquake "1906 San Francisco
earthquake"). The fault returns onshore at [Bolinas
Lagoon](/wiki/Bolinas_Lagoon "Bolinas Lagoon") just north of [Stinson
Beach](/wiki/Stinson_Beach,_California "Stinson Beach, California") in [Marin
County](/wiki/Marin_County "Marin County"). It returns underwater through the
linear trough of [Tomales Bay](/wiki/Tomales_Bay "Tomales Bay") which
separates the [Point Reyes Peninsula](/wiki/Point_Reyes_Peninsula "Point Reyes
Peninsula") from the mainland, runs just east of Bodega Head through Bodega
Bay and back underwater, returning onshore at [Fort Ross](/wiki/Fort_Ross
"Fort Ross"). (In this region around the [San Francisco Bay
Area](/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay_Area "San Francisco Bay Area") several
significant "sister faults" run more-or-less parallel, and each of these can
create significantly destructive earthquakes.) From Fort Ross, the northern
segment continues overland, forming in part a linear valley through which the
[Gualala River](/wiki/Gualala_River "Gualala River") flows. It goes back
offshore at [Point Arena](/wiki/Point_Arena "Point Arena"). After that, it
runs underwater along the coast until it nears [Cape
Mendocino](/wiki/Cape_Mendocino "Cape Mendocino"), where it begins to bend to
the west, terminating at the [Mendocino Triple
Junction](/wiki/Mendocino_Triple_Junction "Mendocino Triple Junction").

### Central[[edit](/w/index.php?title=San_Andreas_Fault&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Central")]

The central segment of the San Andreas Fault runs in a northwestern direction
from Parkfield to [Hollister](/wiki/Hollister,_California "Hollister,
California"). While the southern section of the fault and the parts through
Parkfield experience earthquakes, the rest of the central section of the fault
exhibits a phenomenon called [aseismic creep](/wiki/Aseismic_creep "Aseismic
creep"), where the fault slips continuously without causing earthquakes.

3-D perspective view of Earth's San Andreas Fault in the [Temblor
Range](/wiki/Temblor_Range "Temblor Range")

The southern segment (also known as the [Mojave](/wiki/Mojave_Desert "Mojave
Desert") segment) begins near [Bombay Beach,
California](/wiki/Bombay_Beach,_California#Geography "Bombay Beach,
California"). Box Canyon, near the [Salton Sea](/wiki/Salton_Sea "Salton
Sea"), contains upturned strata associated with that section of the fault.[4]
The fault then runs along the southern base of the [San Bernardino
Mountains](/wiki/San_Bernardino_Mountains "San Bernardino Mountains"), crosses
through the [Cajon Pass](/wiki/Cajon_Pass "Cajon Pass") and continues
northwest along the northern base of the [San Gabriel
Mountains](/wiki/San_Gabriel_Mountains "San Gabriel Mountains"). These
mountains are a result of movement along the San Andreas Fault and are
commonly called the Transverse Range. In [Palmdale](/wiki/Palmdale,_California
"Palmdale, California"), a portion of the fault is easily examined at a
roadcut for the [Antelope Valley Freeway](/wiki/Antelope_Valley_Freeway
"Antelope Valley Freeway"). The fault continues northwest alongside the
Elizabeth Lake Road to the town of [Elizabeth
Lake](/wiki/Elizabeth_Lake,_California "Elizabeth Lake, California"). As it
passes the towns of [Gorman](/wiki/Gorman,_California "Gorman, California"),
[Tejon Pass](/wiki/Tejon_Pass "Tejon Pass") and [Frazier
Park](/wiki/Frazier_Park,_California "Frazier Park, California"), the fault
begins to bend northward, forming the "Big Bend". This [restraining
bend](/wiki/Transpression#Restraining_bend "Transpression") is thought to be
where the fault locks up in [Southern California](/wiki/Southern_California
"Southern California"), with an earthquake-recurrence interval of roughly
140–160 years. Northwest of Frazier Park, the fault runs through the [Carrizo
Plain](/wiki/Carrizo_Plain "Carrizo Plain"), a long, treeless plain where much
of the fault is plainly visible. The Elkhorn Scarp defines the fault trace
along much of its length within the plain.

The southern segment, which stretches from
[Parkfield](/wiki/Parkfield,_California "Parkfield, California") in [Monterey
County](/wiki/Monterey_County,_California "Monterey County, California") all
the way to the [Salton Sea](/wiki/Salton_Sea "Salton Sea"), is capable of an
8.1-magnitude earthquake. At its closest, this fault passes about 35 miles (56
km) to the northeast of Los Angeles. Such a large earthquake on this southern
segment would kill thousands of people in Los Angeles, San Bernardino,
Riverside, and surrounding areas, and cause hundreds of billions of dollars in
damage.[5]

## Plate
boundaries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=San_Andreas_Fault&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Plate boundaries")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-
new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)|
This section **needs additional citations
for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**.
Please help [improve this
article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=San_Andreas_Fault&action=edit)
by [adding citations to reliable
sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1
"Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may
be challenged and removed. _(December 2015)__([Learn how and when to remove
this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal
"Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
The [Pacific Plate](/wiki/Pacific_Plate "Pacific Plate"), to the west of the
fault, is moving in a northwest direction while the [North American
Plate](/wiki/North_American_Plate "North American Plate") to the east is
moving toward the southwest, but relatively southeast under the influence of
[plate tectonics](/wiki/Plate_tectonics "Plate tectonics"). The rate of
slippage averages about 33 to 37 millimeters (1.3 to 1.5 in) a year across
California.[6]

The southwestward motion of the North American Plate towards the Pacific is
creating compressional forces along the eastern side of the fault. The effect
is expressed as the Coast Ranges. The northwest movement of the Pacific Plate
is also creating significant compressional forces which are especially
pronounced where the North American Plate has forced the San Andreas to jog
westward. This has led to the formation of the Transverse Ranges in Southern
California, and to a lesser but still significant extent, the [Santa Cruz
Mountains](/wiki/Santa_Cruz_Mountains "Santa Cruz Mountains") (the location of
the [Loma Prieta earthquake](/wiki/Loma_Prieta_earthquake "Loma Prieta
earthquake") in 1989).

Studies of the relative motions of the Pacific and North American plates have
shown that only about 75 percent of the motion can be accounted for in the
movements of the San Andreas and its various branch faults. The rest of the
motion has been found in an area east of the [Sierra
Nevada](/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_\(U.S.\) "Sierra Nevada \(U.S.\)") mountains
called the [Walker Lane](/wiki/Walker_Lane "Walker Lane") or Eastern
California Shear Zone. The reason for this is not clear. Several hypotheses
have been offered and research is ongoing. One hypothesis – which gained
interest following the [Landers
earthquake](/wiki/Landers,_California_earthquake "Landers, California
earthquake") in 1992 – suggests the plate boundary may be shifting eastward
away from the San Andreas towards Walker Lane.

Assuming the plate boundary does not change as hypothesized, projected motion
indicates that the landmass west of the San Andreas Fault, including Los
Angeles, will eventually slide past San Francisco, then continue northwestward
toward the [Aleutian Trench](/wiki/Aleutian_Trench "Aleutian Trench"), over a
period of perhaps twenty million years.

## Formation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=San_Andreas_Fault&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Formation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/San_Andreas_Fault_Sequential_Diagrams.jpg/310px-
San_Andreas_Fault_Sequential_Diagrams.jpg)](/wiki/File:San_Andreas_Fault_Sequential_Diagrams.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:San_Andreas_Fault_Sequential_Diagrams.jpg "Enlarge")

Tectonic evolution of the San Andreas Fault.

The San Andreas began to form in the mid [Cenozoic](/wiki/Cenozoic "Cenozoic")
about 30 [Mya](/wiki/Mya_\(unit\) "Mya \(unit\)") (million years ago).[7] At
this time, a [spreading center](/wiki/Seafloor_spreading "Seafloor spreading")
between the Pacific Plate and the [Farallon Plate](/wiki/Farallon_Plate
"Farallon Plate") (which is now mostly subducted, with remnants including the
[Juan de Fuca Plate](/wiki/Juan_de_Fuca_Plate "Juan de Fuca Plate"), [Rivera
Plate](/wiki/Rivera_Plate "Rivera Plate"), [Cocos Plate](/wiki/Cocos_Plate
"Cocos Plate"), and the [Nazca Plate](/wiki/Nazca_Plate "Nazca Plate")) was
beginning to reach the subduction zone off the western coast of North America.
As the relative motion between the Pacific and North American Plates was
different from the relative motion between the Farallon and North American
Plates, the spreading ridge began to be "subducted", creating a new relative
motion and a new style of deformation along the plate boundaries. These
geological features are what are chiefly seen along San Andreas Fault. It also
includes a possible driver for the deformation of the [Basin and
Range](/wiki/Basin_and_Range_Province "Basin and Range Province"), separation
of the [Baja California Peninsula](/wiki/Baja_California_Peninsula "Baja
California Peninsula"), and rotation of the [Transverse
Range](/wiki/Transverse_Range "Transverse Range").

The main southern section of the San Andreas Fault proper has only existed for
about 5 million years.[8] The first known incarnation of the southern part of
the fault was Clemens Well-Fenner-[San
Francisquito](/wiki/San_Francisquito_Canyon "San Francisquito Canyon") fault
zone around 22–13 Ma. This system added the [San Gabriel
Fault](/wiki/San_Gabriel_Fault "San Gabriel Fault") as a primary focus of
movement between 10–5 Ma. Currently, it is believed that the modern San
Andreas will eventually transfer its motion toward a fault within the [Eastern
California Shear Zone](/wiki/Eastern_California_Shear_Zone "Eastern California
Shear Zone"). This complicated evolution, especially along the southern
segment, is mostly caused by either the "Big Bend" and/or a difference in the
motion vector between the plates and the trend of the fault and its
surrounding branches.

## Study[[edit](/w/index.php?title=San_Andreas_Fault&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Study")]

### Early
years[[edit](/w/index.php?title=San_Andreas_Fault&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Early years")]

The fault was first identified in Northern California by UC Berkeley geology
professor [Andrew Lawson](/wiki/Andrew_Lawson "Andrew Lawson") in 1895 and
named by him after the _[Laguna de San Andreas](/wiki/Laguna_de_San_Andreas
"Laguna de San Andreas")_ , a small lake which lies in a linear valley formed
by the fault just south of San Francisco. Eleven years later, Lawson
discovered that the San Andreas Fault stretched southward into southern
California after reviewing the effects of the [1906 San Francisco
earthquake](/wiki/1906_San_Francisco_earthquake "1906 San Francisco
earthquake"). Large-scale (hundreds of miles) lateral movement along the fault
was first proposed in a 1953 paper by geologists Mason Hill and [Thomas
Dibblee](/wiki/Thomas_Dibblee "Thomas Dibblee"). This idea, which was
considered radical at the time, has since been vindicated by modern [plate
tectonics](/wiki/Plate_tectonics "Plate tectonics").[9]

### Current
research[[edit](/w/index.php?title=San_Andreas_Fault&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Current research")]

Seismologists discovered that the San Andreas Fault near
[Parkfield](/wiki/Parkfield,_California "Parkfield, California") in central
California consistently produces a magnitude 6.0 earthquake approximately once
every 22 years. Following recorded seismic events in 1857, 1881, 1901, 1922,
1934, and 1966, scientists predicted that another earthquake should occur in
Parkfield in 1993. It eventually occurred in [2004](/wiki/Parkfield_earthquake
"Parkfield earthquake"). Due to the frequency of predictable activity,
Parkfield has become one of the most important areas in the world for large
earthquake research.

In 2004, work began just north of Parkfield on the [San Andreas Fault
Observatory at Depth](/wiki/San_Andreas_Fault_Observatory_at_Depth "San
Andreas Fault Observatory at Depth") (SAFOD). The goal of SAFOD is to drill a
hole nearly 3 kilometres (1.9 mi) into the Earth's crust and into the San
Andreas Fault. An array of sensors will be installed to record earthquakes
that happen near this area.[10]

The San Andreas Fault System has been the subject of a flood of studies. In
particular, scientific research performed during the last 23 years has given
rise to about 3,400 publications.[11]

### The next "Big
One"[[edit](/w/index.php?title=San_Andreas_Fault&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: The next "Big One"")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/NASA_Radar_3-D_View_of_San_Andreas_Fault.jpg/220px-
NASA_Radar_3-D_View_of_San_Andreas_Fault.jpg)](/wiki/File:NASA_Radar_3-D_View_of_San_Andreas_Fault.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:NASA_Radar_3-D_View_of_San_Andreas_Fault.jpg "Enlarge")

[Radar](/wiki/Radar "Radar") generated 3-D view of the San Andreas Fault, at
[Crystal Springs Reservoir](/wiki/Crystal_Springs_Reservoir "Crystal Springs
Reservoir") near [San Mateo, California](/wiki/San_Mateo,_California "San
Mateo, California").[12]

A study published in 2006 in the journal _Nature_ found that the San Andreas
fault has reached a sufficient stress level for an earthquake of magnitude
greater than 7.0 on the [moment magnitude scale](/wiki/Moment_magnitude_scale
"Moment magnitude scale") to occur.[13] This study also found that the risk of
a large earthquake may be increasing more rapidly than scientists had
previously believed. Moreover, the risk is currently concentrated on the
southern section of the fault, i.e. the region around Los Angeles, because
massive earthquakes have occurred relatively recently on the central
([1857](/wiki/Fort_Tejon_earthquake "Fort Tejon earthquake")) and northern
([1906](/wiki/1906_San_Francisco_earthquake "1906 San Francisco earthquake"))
segments of the fault, while the southern section has not seen any similar
rupture for at least 300 years. According to this study, a massive earthquake
on that southern section of the San Andreas fault would result in major damage
to the [Palm Springs](/wiki/Palm_Springs,_California "Palm Springs,
California")-[Indio](/wiki/Indio,_California "Indio, California") metropolitan
area and other cities in [San
Bernardino](/wiki/San_Bernardino_County,_California "San Bernardino County,
California"), [Riverside](/wiki/Riverside_County,_California "Riverside
County, California") and [Imperial](/wiki/Imperial_County,_California
"Imperial County, California") counties in California, and [Mexicali
Municipality](/wiki/Mexicali_Municipality "Mexicali Municipality") in [Baja
California](/wiki/Baja_California_\(state\) "Baja California \(state\)"). It
would be strongly felt (and potentially cause significant damage) throughout
much of [Southern California](/wiki/Southern_California "Southern
California"), including densely populated areas of [Los Angeles
County](/wiki/Los_Angeles_County "Los Angeles County"), [Ventura
County](/wiki/Ventura_County "Ventura County"), [Orange
County](/wiki/Orange_County,_California "Orange County, California"), [San
Diego County](/wiki/San_Diego_County "San Diego County"), [Ensenada
Municipality](/wiki/Ensenada_Municipality "Ensenada Municipality") and
[Tijuana Municipality](/wiki/Tijuana_Municipality "Tijuana Municipality"),
[Baja California](/wiki/Baja_California_\(state\) "Baja California
\(state\)"), [San Luis Rio Colorado](/wiki/San_Luis_Rio_Colorado "San Luis Rio
Colorado") in [Sonora](/wiki/Sonora "Sonora") and [Yuma](/wiki/Yuma,_Arizona
"Yuma, Arizona"), [Arizona](/wiki/Arizona "Arizona"). Older buildings would be
especially prone to damage or collapse, as would buildings built on
unconsolidated gravel or in coastal areas where water tables are high (and
thus subject to [soil liquefaction](/wiki/Soil_liquefaction "Soil
liquefaction")). The paper concluded:

> The information available suggests that the fault is ready for the next big
> earthquake but exactly when the triggering will happen and when the
> earthquake will occur we cannot tell [...] It could be tomorrow or it could
> be 10 years or more from now.[13]

Nevertheless, in the 12 years since that publication there has not been a
substantial quake in the Los Angeles area, and two major reports issued by the
[U.S. Geological Survey](/wiki/U.S._Geological_Survey "U.S. Geological
Survey") (USGS) have made variable predictions as to the risk of future
seismic events. The ability to predict major earthquakes with sufficient
precision to warrant increased precautions has remained elusive.[14]

The [U.S. Geological Survey](/wiki/U.S._Geological_Survey "U.S. Geological
Survey") most recent forecast, known as [UCERF3](/wiki/UCERF3 "UCERF3")
(Uniform California Earthquake Rupture Forecast 3), released in November 2013,
estimated that an earthquake of magnitude 6.7 M or greater (i.e. equal to or
greater than the [1994 Northridge earthquake](/wiki/1994_Northridge_earthquake
"1994 Northridge earthquake")) occurs about once every 6.7 years statewide.
The same report also estimated there is a 7% probability that an earthquake of
magnitude 8.0 or greater will occur in the next 30 years somewhere along the
San Andreas Fault.[15] A different USGS study in 2008 tried to assess the
physical, social and economic consequences of a major earthquake in southern
California. That study predicted that a magnitude 7.8 earthquake along the
southern San Andreas Fault could cause about 1,800 deaths and $213 billion in
damage.[16]

### Cascadia
connection[[edit](/w/index.php?title=San_Andreas_Fault&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Cascadia connection")]

A 2008 paper, studying past earthquakes along the Pacific coastal zone, found
a correlation in time between seismic events on the northern San Andreas Fault
and the southern part of the [Cascadia subduction
zone](/wiki/Cascadia_subduction_zone "Cascadia subduction zone") (which
stretches from [Vancouver Island](/wiki/Vancouver_Island "Vancouver Island")
to northern California). Scientists believe quakes on the Cascadia subduction
zone may have triggered most of the major quakes on the northern San Andreas
within the past 3,000 years. The evidence also shows the rupture direction
going from north to south in each of these time-correlated events. However the
1906 San Francisco earthquake seems to have been the exception to this
correlation because the plate movement was moved mostly from south to north
and it was not preceded by a major quake in the Cascadia zone.[17]

##
Earthquakes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=San_Andreas_Fault&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Earthquakes")]

See also: [List of earthquakes in
California](/wiki/List_of_earthquakes_in_California "List of earthquakes in
California")

The San Andreas Fault has had some notable earthquakes in historic times:

  * [1857 Fort Tejon earthquake](/wiki/1857_Fort_Tejon_earthquake "1857 Fort Tejon earthquake"): About 350 kilometers (220 mi) were ruptured in central and southern California. Though it is known as the [Fort Tejon](/wiki/Fort_Tejon "Fort Tejon") earthquake, the epicenter is thought to have been located far to the north, just south of [Parkfield](/wiki/Parkfield,_California "Parkfield, California"). Two deaths were reported. The [magnitude](/wiki/Richter_magnitude_scale "Richter magnitude scale") was about 7.9.
  * [1906 San Francisco earthquake](/wiki/1906_San_Francisco_earthquake "1906 San Francisco earthquake"): About 430 kilometers (270 mi) were ruptured in Northern California. The epicenter was near [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco"). At least 3,000 people died in the earthquake and subsequent fires. The magnitude was estimated to be 7.8.
  * [1957 San Francisco earthquake](/wiki/1957_San_Francisco_earthquake "1957 San Francisco earthquake"): A magnitude 5.7 quake with an epicenter on the San Andreas fault in the ocean west of San Francisco and Daly City.
  * [1989 Loma Prieta earthquake](/wiki/1989_Loma_Prieta_earthquake "1989 Loma Prieta earthquake"): About 40 kilometers (25 mi) were ruptured (although the rupture did not reach the surface) near [Santa Cruz, California](/wiki/Santa_Cruz,_California "Santa Cruz, California"), causing 63 deaths and moderate damage in certain vulnerable locations in the San Francisco Bay Area. [Moment magnitude](/wiki/Moment_magnitude_scale "Moment magnitude scale") was about 6.9. This quake occurred on October 17, 1989, at approximately 5:04 PM PDT.
  * 2004 [Parkfield earthquake](/wiki/Parkfield_earthquake "Parkfield earthquake"): On September 28, 2004 at 10:15 a.m. PDT, a magnitude 6.0 earthquake struck the Parkfield area. It was felt across the state, including the San Francisco Bay Area.
